children.prompt: Pick two of the words, and for each word describe a sentence you would use that includes that word and what you mean by the word.
If you double the mass of an object, how much more (or less) force is required to make it accelerate at the same rate?

choices.content: a) The same amount.
b) Twice as much.
c) Half as much.
d) Four times as much.
e) One-fourth as much.

children.prompt: Describe what happened when the egg was thrown into the sheet. Did the sheet move?
Can you think of a practical example in which some tool is used to let you exert a smaller force over a larger distance?
If you jump into the air and land back on your feet, is your momentum always the same? If not, what else has to change its momentum?

We have all seen skaters at parks or in videos. As you proceed in this lesson, keep in mind the motion of the skater as she goes up and down in the pipe. Record what you remember about skating in the box below.
What would happen to the skater if the right hand side of the ramp were removed?
How would the kinetic and potential energies of a skater compare as she skates down a ramp if the right hand side of the ramp were removed?
Observe and record what happens to the kinetic and gravitational potential energies as the skater moves down the ramp.
Predict what the sum of these energies is and any changes to the sum of the energies.  Support your prediction with evidence from the simulation.

children.drawing_prompt: Record the results of your experiment.

children.prompt: Describe what happens to the kinetic, gravitational potential, and total energies as the skater slides down ramps with different heights.
How does the gravitational potential energy of the skater at the beginning of the ramp vary as the height of the ramp is increased? Include your observations of the height of the ramp at 4 meters.
Where do you think the gravitational potential energy that the skater has at the top of the ramp comes from?
Record any general observations you have made as you ran this activity.
How well does this simulation model a real-world skater on a ramp? Explain in what ways the real-world skater is similar to this simulation and in what ways it is different.

As you may have seen in the PhET simulation, you can change the physical location of the skater and ramp to a different gravitational field. Discuss how you think the skater's motion would be changed if you were to allow her to skate in another location.

If you were asked to perform some conservation of energy calculations in this skater scenario, where would be the best place to set the potential energy reference of the system? Would the outcome of the energy conservation law change depending on where this reference is set? Why or why not?
Verify your prediction: What happens if you change the reference point for gravitational potential energy?
What is the best placement of the reference point for gravitational potential energy in this simulation? Justify your answer.
Try using the simulation to build a loop-the-loop. How high must you release the skater in order to allow her to stay on the loop?

When a skater is at the top of the loop-the-loop, how do the kinetic energy, gravitational potential energy, and total energy compare with the values of these energies at the top and bottom of the ramp?
The speed of a mass sliding down a frictionless ramp depends on:

choices.content: a) its mass.
b) the change in height of the object.
c) the shape of the ramp.
d) All of the above.
a) Both will have the same speed.
b) Cannot be calculated without more information.
c) Mass that dropped in free fall.
d) Mass that slid down ramp.

children.prompt: Which will have a higher final speed, a mass dropped from the top of a cliff (free fall) or a mass which slides down a frictionless ramp from the top of the cliff to the bottom?

choices.content: a) Both will reach the bottom at the same time.
b) Cannot be calculated without more information.
c) Mass that dropped in free fall.
d) Mass that slid down the ramp.

children.prompt: Which will reach the bottom first, a mass dropped from the top of a cliff (free fall) or a mass which slides down a frictionless ramp from the top of the cliff to the bottom?
A block initially at rest slides down a frictionless ramp and achieves a velocity v at the bottom. To achieve a velocity of 2v, the height of the ramp must be:

choices.content: a) the same height.
b) twice the original height.
c) four times the original height.
d) cannot be calculated without more information about the mass of the block.

children.prompt: One of the earliest machines used by humans was the ramp. We all know that using a ramp makes lifting heavy objects easier. List some examples of when ramps were used in history or in your own life.
How will the work done by the applied force and the increase in gravitational potential energy of the file cabinet compare with one another in the absence of friction?
How will the work done by the applied force and the increase in gravitational potential energy of the file cabinet compare with one another when friction acts on the system?

children.drawing_prompt: Document your calculations in the tables by taking a snapshot.

children.prompt: How does the force needed to slide the file cabinet up the ramp compare with the weight of the file cabinet in both the situation without friction and the situation with friction?
How does the work done against gravity and the increase in the file cabinet's gravitational potential energy compare in both the situation without friction and the situation with friction?

How does the work done in sliding the file cabinet along the ramp and the work done against gravity in lifting the file cabinet compare in both the situation without friction and the situation with friction?
Based on your answers to the questions above, what are the advantages of using a ramp to lift a heavy object? What are the disadvantages of using a ramp to lift a heavy object?
Based off of your recorded observations (when friction was present), for which configuration was the friction due to the ramp the highest? The lowest? Explain your reasoning behind your answers.

Discuss the relationship observed between work done to push the object up the ramp when friction is present and the change in potential energy of the object. How does this compare to the cases where friction was not present?

choices.content: a) Yes, he will have just enough energy to finish the move.
b) No, he will not even come close to moving the final dresser.
c) Yes, he can, but he will need to move it slowly to conserve his energy.

children.prompt: After a long day of moving furniture, Mike has one final dresser to move up a frictionless ramp onto the moving truck. Mike estimates that he only has about 1000 J of energy left in him before he collapses due to exhaustion. If the truck's bed is 1 m off the ground, will Mike have enough energy move the 100 kg dresser?

choices.content: a) The astronaut could push the rover up a ramp 6 times higher on the Moon than on the Earth.
b) If the mass of the rovers are the same it will take the same amount of energy to push the rover up ramps of the same height on the Earth and Moon.
c) The astronaut would expend less energy both on the Moon and Earth if he tried to just lift the rover directly onto the spacecraft.

children.prompt: 2) The Earth's Moon has a gravitational acceleration about 1/6th of Earth's. Which of the following statements would be true about an astronaut pushing a rover up a ramp onto a spacecraft both on the Moon and the Earth?
Name three common objects you encounter every day that exhibit the transfer of kinetic energy to gravitational potential energy (and/or vice versa).

children.name: Gravitational Potential Energy and Work Section

children.prompt: Who is correct, John or Mike?  Which way is easier?
Which process will require less energy?
Which process will require more force?
How much work is required to lift a mass, m, a height, h? Assume that the mass is at rest at the top and bottom of its path.

children.drawing_prompt: Record the data of your experiment here.

children.prompt: Use your observations and calculations to justify Mike's argument, where the movers lift the refrigerator straight up and into the van without the ramp.
Use your observations and calculations to justify John's argument, where the movers push the refrigerator into the van along the ramp.
Discuss how the slope of the ramp will affect the results. What kind of slope will result in the most friction?

Which requires less energy:

a. Lifting an object with a constant force.

b. Lifting an object with a sudden force of changing strength.

Explain.

choices.content: a) depends on the weight of the barbell.
b) cannot be calculated without more information.
c) is equal to zero.

children.prompt: A woman holds a barbell in a fixed position. The work she does on the barbell:
A man pushes a refrigerator across a horizontal floor. The work done by gravity on the refrigerator is:

choices.content: a) depends on the weight of the refrigerator.
b) cannot be calculated without more information.
c) is equal to zero.
a) decreases.
b) increases.
c) remains the same.
d) cannot be found without more information about the way the work was done.

children.prompt: When positive work is done on an object, its kinetic energy:

choices.content: a) It was positive.
b) It was zero.
c) It was negative.

children.prompt: In our experiment the kinetic energy of the refrigerator did not change; it started from rest and finished at rest. What can you say about the total work done on the object?
How is the amount that a spring stretches related to the amount of mass suspended from that spring?
What will happen to gravitational potential energy, elastic potential energy, kinetic energy, and total energy as a suspended mass oscillates on a spring?

children.drawing_prompt: Record your data from the simulation with a snapshot.

children.prompt: How is the amount of displacement of the spring related to the amount of gravitational force applied to it? Use your data to calculate the elastic constant of the spring.

How would the observations you made in the exercise above change with a spring which is softer or harder (smaller or larger elastic constant) than your original spring? That is, which would elongate more with a given force, a softer spring or a harder spring?

children.drawing_prompt: Record your measurements and calculations with a snapshot.

children.prompt: In which spring does a force produce more elongation, a soft spring or a hard spring? Justify your answers using the observations you made and support your conclusions with mathematical reasoning.
Which would have a greater elastic constant, a soft spring or a hard spring? Justify your answers using the observations you made and support your conclusions with mathematical reasoning.
What will happen to gravitational potential energy, elastic potential energy, kinetic energy, and total energy as a suspended mass oscillates on a spring?

children.drawing_prompt: Record you observations with a snapshot.

children.prompt: How do the gravitational potential energy, elastic potential energy, kinetic energy, and total energy of this system vary as the mass travels through its oscillations? How are your observations consistent with what you have previously learned by studying a mass and ramp?

The distance a mass falls, while connected to a spring, depends on the magnitude of the mass.

If three different masses are "dropped" while connected to a spring, which will drop more; a smaller mass or a larger mass?

children.drawing_prompt: Record your measurements with a snapshot.

children.prompt: Describe the relationship between the distance that a mass drops and the amount of mass being dropped. Is it a direct relationship? Explain why you think the relationship is as you observe.
A ball falls from a window 20 meters above a vertical (ideal) spring. How high will the ball "bounce?" Ignore air resistance.

choices.content: a) The answer depends on the spring constant.
b) Since energy is conserved it will bounce a distance equal to the compression of the spring.
c) It will return to its original height of 20 meters.
d) Different balls will go to greatly different heights.
a) greater for the spring with constant K.
b) greater for the spring with constant k.
c) the same because energy is conserved.

children.prompt: Two springs have different spring constants K > k. The amount of work to stretch them the same amount is:

A mass is attached to a horizontal spring, oscillating on a frictionless table. The maximum speed a 5 kg mass has oscillating is 2 m/s, which occurs at the middle of its oscillation. The total distance of oscillation, from left to right, is 2 meters. What is the maximum elastic potential energy?

choices.content: a) 10 J
b) 49 J
c) 59 J

children.name: Forces and Energy in a Spring Section
Forces and Energy in a Spring

children.prompt:
Brittany wants to bungee jump from a bridge. What does she need to know in order to calculate if she can safely jump without hitting the river below?

Image Girl Jumping by lookcatalog, Flickr, CC-BY.
How can you determine the elastic constant of the elastic band?
Record your measurement of the mass of the object (bungee jumper) connected to the elastic band.
Measure the unstretched length of the elastic band. Measure the length of the elastic band when it is stretched by the hanging the "jumper" after it has come to rest. Record these values.
<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_Preliminary.html" width="379px" height="200px" frameborder="0"></iframe>

<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_PredictQ3.html" width="379px" height="250px" frameborder="0"></iframe>
<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_PredictQ4.html" width="379px" height="105px" frameborder="0"></iframe>
Measure the distance the mass falls when it starts from a height even with the attachment point at the top. Make several measurements and record your results below.

How do the results change if the mass is not dropped from directly below the attachment point at the top, but is held horizontally to the side at the same height? Are the results the same or different?

children.drawing_prompt: Record your measurements with a snapshot.

children.prompt: Does your measured value of the distance the mass drops agree with your predicted value? If there is a discrepancy, explain why it occurs and suggest how this discrepancy might be resolved.
<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_Explain.html" width="379px" height="175px" frameborder="0"></iframe>
If you were designing a bungee jump from a bridge, what factors would you consider?
<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_AssessQ1.html" width="379px" height="100px" frameborder="0"></iframe>

choices.content: a) The one attached to the cord with elastic constant k.
b) The one attached to the cord with elastic constant K.
c) They will fall the same distance.

children.prompt: <iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_AssessQ2.html" width="379px" height="100px" frameborder="0"></iframe>

choices.content: a) They will fall the same distance.
b) Mass M will fall the furthest.
c) Mass m will fall the furthest.
a) The constants are the same.
b) The constant for the longer cord is larger.
c) The constant for the shorter cord is larger.

children.prompt: Two bungee cords are identical except one is twice as long as the other. How are their elastic constants related?
<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Bungee_AssessQ4.html" width="379px" height="140px" frameborder="0"></iframe>

choices.content: a) It will be higher.
b) It will be the same.
c) It will be lower.

children.prompt: If a bungee jumper leaps up in the air rather than just dropping, how will his lowest point compare to the point he would reach by just dropping?
When you do positive work on a particle, its kinetic energy:

choices.content: a) increases.
b) decreases.
c) remains the same.
d) cannot be calculated without more information about how the work was done.

children.prompt: A woman holds a bowling ball above her head at a constant height. The work she does on the ball:

choices.content: a) depends on the weight of the ball.
b) cannot be calculated without more information.
c) is equal to zero.
a) depends on the weight of the load.
b) cannot be calculated given the information provided.
c) is equal to zero.

children.prompt: A man pushes a heavy load across a horizontal floor. The work that gravity does on the load:
<iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Assessment_Hockey.html" width="379px" height="160px" frameborder="0"></iframe>

choices.content: a) Puck A
b) Puck B
c) The kinetic energy is the same for A and B.
d) Cannot be calculated given the information provided.

children.prompt: The potential energy of a spring is:

choices.content: a) proportional to the distance the spring is stretched.
b) proportional to the square of the distance the spring is stretched.
c) stays the same no matter how far the spring is stretched.
a) The car's kinetic energy decreases.
b) Heat is generated.
c) The energy of the road/car/air system is constant.
d) All of the above.
e) None of the above.

children.prompt: A car slows down as a result of air resistance. Which of the following is true?
Two marbles, one twice as massive as the other, are dropped from the roof of a building. When the two marbles reach the ground, the heavier marble has:

choices.content: a) as much kinetic energy as the lighter one.
b) twice as much kinetic energy as the lighter one.
c) half as much kinetic energy as the lighter one.
d) four times as much kinetic energy as the lighter one.

children.prompt: <iframe src="http://static.ritesproject.net/investigations/energy_conservation/html/Energy_Assessment_Block.html" width="379px" height="100px" frameborder="0"></iframe>

choices.content: a) the same height.
b) twice the original height.
c) four times the original height.
d) cannot determine without knowing the mass of the block.
a) A force can do work only if it points in the direction of the displacement.
b) Only the component of force parallel to the displacement does work.
c) The component of force perpendicular to the displacement does work.
d) Only the net force on an object does work.

children.prompt: Which of the following about work is true?
Which of the following about kinetic energy is true?

choices.content: a) It can be a positive or negative quantity.
b) It is usually a positive quantity, unless the object is moving in a negative direction.
c) It can only be a positive quantity.
